author: {"id": 1531904, "name": "Matthew Fernandez", "state": "active", "web_url": "https://gitlab.com/smattr", "username": "smattr", "avatar_url": "https://gitlab.com/uploads/-/system/user/avatar/1531904/avatar.png"}

body:
In relation to this, I am also unsure why `GVLayout` has defaulted copy constructors. AFAICT it is not safe to copy this class. The shared pointers will be duplicated (which is fine), but then you'll get duplicated calls to `gvFreeLayout` in the destructors (which is not fine).

@magjac do you know why we enabled the copy constructors in this class?

body: While this behavior seems to be deliberate given the wording of the error message ("ignored"), I think it would be much better to fail so the user understands they've done something wrong. The real reason for me wanting to have this functionality changed now is that I want to be able to add options testing to the tools test added in https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/1592 and checking that unsupported options are detected would be the first step in order to avoid that incorrect testing of other options silently fail.

Thank you for diagnosing this problem.

I vote for choice 2, as it seems more general. I admit I don't understand all the implications. For one thing, I'm not sure of all the configuration files involved. (I just noticed mdfind block.h doesn't find vpsc.vcxproj, but grep does. Rebuild Spotlight index?)

Again, we appreciate the help.

author: {"id": 2309476, "name": "Alexandre Duret-Lutz", "state": "active", "web_url": "https://gitlab.com/adl1", "username": "adl1", "avatar_url": "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/5c84850c885cf24c7cf688467df9fb99?s=80&d=identicon"}

body:
It appears the latest version of vmalloc is five years old and can be found at https://github.com/padsproj/pads/tree/master/ast-ast/src/lib/libast/vmalloc
(not sure why it is not part of https://github.com/att/ast) and significant work
has been done on sbrkmem() which gets raw memory, to make it run in various
operating systems.  #ifdef cray is gone, ha, ha.  It appears it can invoke
mmap() or even the standard malloc() as a last resort.  

Porting this to graphviz would require making sure that it doesn't break 
the current windows build on Appveyor with whatever set of defines and
build-time configuration tests that we rely on.  

Stephen North
author: {"id": 1631868, "name": "Stephen C. North", "state": "active", "web_url": "https://gitlab.com/truenorth", "username": "truenorth", "avatar_url": "https://gitlab.com/uploads/-/system/user/avatar/1631868/avatar.png"}

body:
Hi. It’s possible. A while ago we tried to fix all memory leaks but they
may have crept in. Can you identify the source code that creates this leak?
What are the 2287 objects? It could be onetime code in some underlying
library that stores its own internal data so not really a “leak” per se.
what if you wrap your test in a loop, does it leak on every iteration? I
tend to doubt that.

good news: Things have improved by Graphviz version: `dot - graphviz version 2.47.4~dev.20210622.1734 (20210622.1734)`.  It no longer core dumps.  
bad news:  It now produces this error message:  `Error: in routesplines, cannot find NORMAL edge` and it produces an incorrect graph (`n5->n1` and the second `n1->n5` are missing):

The possible issue with rewriting mkdefs.c in some other language is that the "new" language compiler/interpreter is now required by the build process.  
Are any scripting languages already required?
author: {"id": 1773206, "name": "steve roush", "state": "active", "web_url": "https://gitlab.com/steveroush", "username": "steveroush", "avatar_url": "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/8b150d04c47a4e4dcb32ad76a265ed61?s=80&d=identicon"}

body: Doing some more reading on the topic, it seems most libcs have decided `qsort_s` is a poor API and chosen not to implement it (e.g. https://www.openwall.com/lists/musl/2018/09/03/3). Every platform Graphviz supports seems to have a better equivalent, so I’ll look into replacement with this now.
author: {"id": 1531904, "name": "Matthew Fernandez", "state": "active", "web_url": "https://gitlab.com/smattr", "username": "smattr", "avatar_url": "https://gitlab.com/uploads/-/system/user/avatar/1531904/avatar.png"}

body: Would we prefer to call this C++ *bindings* instead of a C++ *API*?
author: {"id": 275623, "name": "Magnus Jacobsson", "state": "active", "web_url": "https://gitlab.com/magjac", "username": "magjac", "avatar_url": "https://gitlab.com/uploads/-/system/user/avatar/275623/avatar.png"}

body:
Thanks for digging into this. It’s surprisingly complicated!

<details><summary>...</summary>

On Mon, 11 Apr 2022 at 03:53, Matthew Fernandez (@smattr) < gitlab@mg.gitlab.com> wrote:

> Matthew Fernandez <https://gitlab.com/smattr> created an issue: #2229
> <https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/2229>
>
> Migrating this from !2575 (comment 907097811)
> <https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/2575#note_907097811>
> :
>
> I implemented itos believing lifetime of an rvalue
> <https://en.cppreference.com/w/c/language/value_category> like this to be
> the extent of the containing expression. However, your question made me
> delve in to try to find chapter and verse in the C standard to back this
> up. I realized I'm wrong and I was thinking of the equivalent scenario in
> C++ (which would involve what they term a prvalue
> <https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/value_category#prvalue>). In
> C, the situation apparently differs between C99 and C11, for which there is
> a helpful example https://en.cppreference.com/w/c/language/lifetime.
>
> The tl;dr of this is that use of itos like this is unfortunately undefined
> behavior <https://en.cppreference.com/w/c/language/behavior> in C99, the
> mode in which we compile Graphviz. We should probably look at removing
> itos and its uses, which is disappointing as I introduced it aiming to
> solve a number of sprintf problems.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitLab
> <https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/2229>.
> You're receiving this email because of your account on gitlab.com. If
> you'd like to receive fewer emails, you can unsubscribe
> <https://gitlab.com/-/sent_notifications/REDACTED/unsubscribe>
> from this thread or adjust your notification settings.
>

</details>

body: Could you attach the file? Generally graph layout is a pretty computationally intensive problem, I wouldn’t be surprised if a huge graph like that is having trouble laying out.

body:
I am seeing this build failure as well.

```
  CC       vmwalk.lo
malloc.c:331:15: error: return type is an incomplete type
 struct mstats mstats(void)
               ^
malloc.c: In function 'mstats':
malloc.c:334:19: error: storage size of 'ms' isn't known
     struct mstats ms;
                   ^
```

gcc 5.5.0
Graphviz 2.40.1

body:
This is a good suggestion.  To my knowledge, x86_64 is already being built in
https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ellson/graphviz-pl238 <https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ellson/graphviz-pl238>
Also I see an installer is generated, but it does not look big enough to actually
contain the software (it is just 4 megs so something probably went wrong).
Actually I’m surprised because I thought we just put all the build artifacts in
a zip file and it would be up to the, er, consumer to figure out what to do with it.

Someone would need to look into this further but it appears a lot of the work
was already done.

Stephen North

body: Actually I just realized unistd.h is already shimmed in windows/include/unistd.h. So given windows/include is in the include path during compilation on Windows, is there any platform for which `#include <unistd.h>` does not work within the Graphviz code base? The solution for the warning in the OP may just be to add an unconditional `#include <unistd.h>`.

author: {"id": 275623, "name": "Magnus Jacobsson", "state": "active", "web_url": "https://gitlab.com/magjac", "username": "magjac", "avatar_url": "https://gitlab.com/uploads/-/system/user/avatar/275623/avatar.png"}

body:
I have no idea what's going on, but it seems that I managed to fix it anyway. I removed the braces and that seems to work for both Linux and Windows CMake, see https://gitlab.com/magjac/graphviz/-/pipelines/181760767. For MSBuild there's something else that goes wrong. I guess it has something to do with this:
```
find . -name '*.vcxproj' -exec grep -HnI yy {} \;
./cmd/tools/gml2gv.vcxproj:76:sed "s/yy/gml/g" < gmlscan-intermediate.c > gmlscan.c
./cmd/tools/gml2gv.vcxproj:79:sed "s/yy/gml/g" < gmlparse-intermediate.h > gmlparse.h
./cmd/tools/gml2gv.vcxproj:80:sed "s/yy/gml/g" < gmlparse-intermediate.c > gmlparse.c
./cmd/tools/gml2gv.vcxproj:105:sed "s/yy/gml/g" < gmlscan-intermediate.c > gmlscan.c
./cmd/tools/gml2gv.vcxproj:108:sed "s/yy/gml/g" < gmlparse-intermediate.h > gmlparse.h
./cmd/tools/gml2gv.vcxproj:109:sed "s/yy/gml/g" < gmlparse-intermediate.c > gmlparse.c
./lib/expr/expr.vcxproj:68:sed "s/yy/ex/g" < exparse-intermediate.c | sed "s/YY/EX/g" > exparse.c
./lib/expr/expr.vcxproj:69:sed "s/yy/ex/g" < exparse-intermediate.h | sed "s/YY/EX/g" > exparse.h
./lib/expr/expr.vcxproj:86:sed "s/yy/ex/g" < exparse-intermediate.c | sed "s/YY/EX/g" > exparse.c
./lib/expr/expr.vcxproj:87:sed "s/yy/ex/g" < exparse-intermediate.h | sed "s/YY/EX/g" > exparse.h
./lib/gvc.vcxproj:76:sed "s/yy/html/g" < common\htmlparse-intermediate.c > common\htmlparse.c
./lib/gvc.vcxproj:77:sed "s/yy/html/g" < common\htmlparse-intermediate.h > common\htmlparse.h
./lib/gvc.vcxproj:111:sed "s/yy/html/g" < common\htmlparse-intermediate.c > common\htmlparse.c
./lib/gvc.vcxproj:112:sed "s/yy/html/g" < common\htmlparse-intermediate.h > common\htmlparse.h
```
I can have a look at that later today

body: We don't support Windows 7 as it's EOL, but I suspect this is reproducible on Windows 10 too. The problem is likely that `_WIN32` is defined on MinGW but it also doesn't understand `__declspec` so it gets confused about the definitions in lib/cdt/cdt.h.

author: {"id": 1531904, "name": "Matthew Fernandez", "state": "active", "web_url": "https://gitlab.com/smattr", "username": "smattr", "avatar_url": "https://gitlab.com/uploads/-/system/user/avatar/1531904/avatar.png"}

body:
I would actually do a bit more complex variant of this (and is what I meant with regards to ceremony about declarations).  On Linux, you can take advantage of this to use protected visibility, which disables symbol interpositioning which is enabled by default.  This avoids a small penalty by avoiding the PLT for the local symbols (though it may be problematic if you are relying on COPY relocations or if you are relying on certain behaviours with certain TLS models).  Additionally, the snippet that you have does not account for static libraries on Windows, which actually is a problem (you will encounter either warning 4216 or 4217 from link due to the incorrect use of DLL storage for a non-DLL object set).

```c
#if defined(_WIN32)
# if defined(_DLL)
#   if defined(gvc_EXPORTS)
#     define GVC_API __declspec(dllexport)
#   else
#     define GVC_API __declspec(dllimport)
#   endif
# else
#  define GVC_API
# endif
#elif defined(__ELF__)
# if defined(gvc_EXPORTS)
#   define GVC_API __attribute__((__visibility__("default")))
# else
#   if defined(__linux__)
#     define GVC_API __attribute__((__visibility__("protected")))
#   else
#     define GVC_API __attribute__((__visibility__("default")))
#   endif
# endif
#elif defined(__wasm__)
# define GVC_API __attribute__((__visibility__("default")))
#else /* assume MachO */
# define GVC_API __attribute__((__visibility__("default")))
#endif
```

The check for Linux is because Linux is the only OS that I know that has taken advantage of the protected visibility from ELF.  The BSDs do not support it.  The DLL storage case is not perfect, but near enough for a first approximation.  It currently is not correct for the PlayStation and  OS/2 at least off the top of my head, and I'd like to say AIX also (due to XCOFF).
author: {"id": 8753381, "name": "Saleem Abdulrasool", "state": "active", "web_url": "https://gitlab.com/abdulras", "username": "abdulras", "avatar_url": "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/da19a5d4e7742fcd8aacfbabb4c58cc0?s=80&d=identicon"}

body:
Interesting. We would gain some abstractions. Possibly at the cost of
having to choose a C++ subset(?).

How much of the code is in C++ already? A tiny bit was my understanding.

<details><summary>...</summary>

On Wed, 17 Nov 2021 at 13:46, Matthew Fernandez (@smattr) < gitlab@mg.gitlab.com> wrote:

> Matthew Fernandez <https://gitlab.com/smattr> created an issue: #2154
> <https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/2154>
>
> There are a few pieces of Graphviz that are written in C, but are not
> usable without linking against libc++/libstdc++. E.g.
> cmd/mingle/minglemain.c. It seems like nothing is gained from this being in
> C.
>
> Should we consider porting some of this to C++? In the case of
> minglemain.c for example, this would allow dropping the use of agxbufs
> and just using std::ostringstream.
>

body:
@steveroush is this still relevant? [Wikipedia describes VML](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vector_Markup_Language) as:

> an obsolete XML-based file format for two-dimensional vector graphics. It was specified in Part 4 of the Office Open XML standards ISO/IEC 29500 and ECMA-376. According to the specification, VML is a deprecated format included in Office Open XML for legacy reasons only.
author: {"id": 1531904, "name": "Matthew Fernandez", "state": "active", "web_url": "https://gitlab.com/smattr", "username": "smattr", "avatar_url": "https://gitlab.com/uploads/-/system/user/avatar/1531904/avatar.png"}
